values: I hate seeing images of the Towers on fire and falling down. I just hate it. I won't watch any documentaries about that day and quickly change the channel whenever I happen to come by footage of anything having to do with that day. The closest connection that I have to anyone affected is my friend's relative being on one of the planes, but I didn't know him so I came out of that day with no one close to me being injured or killed, thank God. Even so, it took me years to stop having dreams in which airplanes that were on fire fell out of the sky. I still think the Empire State Building looks so lonely whenever I see the NYC skyline and I still stare at planes that seem to be flying too low. These goddamn fucktards at the RNC put together a 9/11 video complete with footage of the Towers on fire and people falling to their deaths. I hate these people to the point that I can't even write too much without wanting to choke someone. All I hope is that, one day, Rudy Giuliani gets locked up in a room with a bunch of pissed-off firefighters.

I will eventually write a real update. This is not that update. Anyway. The Olympics Opening Ceremony were yesterday and, yes, I watched. I don't watch many of the athletic events, but mah gawd, I will park my ass in front of the television for the Opening and Closing Ceremonies. China's government is full of censorship-happy, liberty-crushing propagandists, but I knew they would put on a hell of a show. And they did and I loved most of it, even though I rolled my eyes a bit in certain bits involving schoolchildren. A bunch of kids in the middle of a swarm of blinking green people. What? But the scroll, the costumes, the drums, the lighting of the torch, the fireworks, the weird blocks that kept going up and down, all that stuff: gold. My immediate reaction to the smiling face/sun on the scroll was that they put it there to lull us into false complacency while they quickly replace us as the world's premier superpower. I'm on to you, China! I won't lie, I stayed tuned in to the parade of nations to see hot athletes and national outfits. From what I can remember, someone apparently bled all over the women of Hungary, Israel looked like it just came back from a day at a country club, and the USA looked like a bunch of ship captains. Damn you, Ralph Lauren! And to go into the really shallow end of the pool: I never quite got the hotness of the Olympic athletes whose looks get a bunch of attention. Like, I've never considered anyone on the US swimming team attractive and they seem to get the most media. Just meh. I thought I spotted a really hot one in the USA team until I looked closer and saw that it was LeBron James, like how in the hell did I not see it was LeBron James straight off the bat? I'm blaming Ralph Lauren yet again, especially since looking at that outfit again has made me realize that Team USA could also pass for flight attendants. Anyway, I discovered what the problem was, why I never really went "Whoa!" when faced with some Olympic athlete's looks. Both Gambia and Sweden were hiding this one from me: Gambia and Sweden ! Dude already had his boxing match and lost against some other dude from India (I don't know boxing and I'm not even going to pretend to know boxing), so my eye candy will disappear until the Closing Ceremony. I guess I'll still have LeBron? Who apparently defected to Great Britain when we weren't looking. Look, just because your last King James sucked doesn't mean you get to take ours. Give him back! I'm not even getting into Youngs' China-lovin'.

My first meme, courtesy of
library_of_sex
:

Comment and I'll list 7 interests from your profile in a reply. Then you do an entry about what they mean and why you are interested in them.

1. Mad Season - Layne Staley's band! No, the other one. It was a group formed by members of Alice In Chains, Pearl Jam (those folks get around), and Screaming Trees. They released only one album, Above, as time and drug issues made it difficult to produce anything else. Anyway, Layne Staley is one of my favorite singers, probably only beaten by Chris Cornell, so I love all of his music. Dude could have had just clanging pots and pans backing him up and I would still love it. Favorite song from the album is probably X-Ray Mind. Laaaaaayne. Laaaaaayne with Jerry Cantrell, which is a bit weird but still works.

2. Alison Weir - Weir's a historian/author and one of the major reasons that I went all nuts with the Tudors. I was browsing around Barnes and Noble one day years ago and picked up her book, The Six Wives of Henry VIII, and just decided to buy it right there since it looked interesting enough. That one purchase has led me to a little library of books on British royalty and and a trip to England, which could have been better so I hope to do it again. Stupid worthless dollar. I recognize her biases in that book now, but I still really like it and now that my brother is reading up on the subject (due to Showtime's The Tudors), I gave him that book as an introduction to the whole soap opera.

3. Puerto Rico - My family's island! Chances are that if you have ever been to Aguadilla, Puerto Rico, you have met someone connected to my family. We're all over the place. Most of my family lives down there, which kind of sucks when you have no cousins or aunts anywhere near you. But, at least, when I go to Puerto Rico, I have a whole bunch of places that I could stay at. I used to go every summer but have slowed down to going every few years. As a result, my spoken Spanish is horrendous. The island itself is so beautiful, though, and the thing I miss most about it (other than my family) is its nighttime. You could look up and actually see stars (as opposed to the weird purple night of NYC) and you fall asleep to the sounds of crickets and the coqui (sound can be heard here). When I was younger, the latter scared me a bit during one particular summer when all I could think about is the chupacabra, but other than that, it's always been music. Between El Morro, El Yunque, Gilligan's Island at Guanica, and Old San Juan in general, it's one of the most beautiful places on Earth and I won't hear otherwise.

4. English Royalty - This should probably be "British Royalty," but I wrote that interest in when I was focused on the Tudors and those that came right before, which are technically English kings/queens. I've since dived into the Stuarts and the Hanovers, a bit. Like I said above, it's all a big soap opera for me, except with decapitations and castle imprisonment in place of bitchslapping someone into a pool. I went to England to see all of these places that they were connected to and I wish I was able to go to more places but, screw it, I got to see Hampton Court Palace and Elizabeth I's tomb and all that and everything was beautiful. Reading about it all before actually heading over there made my trip better.

5. Milo's Cookie Dance - This is name after my aunt's dog, Milo. My Aunt Iris and Uncle Henry lived in New York City years ago and I used to hang around with them so much that the bodega guy near them thought that I was Uncle Henry's daughter. They moved to Puerto Rico in the 90s and my uncle passed a few years afterwards but he left behind a gift: a dog who danced. First, let me describe this dog, who is seriously the best dog ever: he is a golden retriever mixed in with a dachshund (a.k.a. a 'sausage dog'). He has the head, coat, and tail of a golden retriever with the body of dachshund, so at one point in this life, there was a female dachshund who was completely flattened or a male dachshund strutting around, thinking he was the shit. I wish I had a scanner to show you how this dog looks. Anyway, Milo's addicted to dog biscuits, which we all call cookies. He got the brains of a golden retriever, so not only did he figure out that the word "Cookie" meant that he was going to get a biscuit, but he also learned out how to spell "Cookie." So someone just have to say "Ceeeeee" and he goes on high alert, looking at the person while perking up his ears and tilting his head. As the person spells on, he goes from a little twirl to a full-on twirl that also includes hops. It is so cute. This is the indoor version. My aunt has a house with the front yard and back yard attached, so if you say the word or start spelling it outdoors, he starts off with the head-tilting and twirl and, in his most frenzied moments, actually runs around the house at full speed. Unfortunately, he's getting sort of old, so he sticks with the twirl most of the time now. So whenever something makes me really happy, I say I'm doing Milo's cookie dance. I miss him so much.

6. Golden Girls - This is just one of the best shows ever. It never, ever gets old and I still can't believe what they got away with for that time. When I was younger, I was always switching between who was my favorite, but it's now carved in stone: Blanche. Blanche ruled all. And this is the scene that made it so. "My God, I'm hallucinating! I see little balls of sunshine in a bag. Does this mean something?" "I can trust you, I know I can, you're from Minnesota. People from Minnesota are honest, they don't lie. What could you possibly find to lie about in a farm? Must be some state. Lots of lakes, lots of pale people. I'd drown myself." A Golden Girls marathon on Lifetime means me not moving my ass from the couch for hours.

7. Suspicious Chihuahuas -

This is my cousin's dog, Kokito. He's suspicious of everything that you do.

Real update coming soon, but I just have to post:



What is this I feel? Pride? Oh my God, it's pride. Priiiiiiiide! And happiness! YAY!



Now go get 'em!





*Cowboy shot from here, yo.

Baseball-wise, one of the only things worse than the Yankees losing to the Red Sox is the Yankees losing to the Red Sox in a game in which the latter uses one of my favorite players. Freaking wrong uniform-wearin' Beckett.

Welcome to the inside of the IZOD Center: Obamafied: Senator Obama had been running around the country, trying to fit in as many of these rallies/speeches as he can, so his speeches are pretty much all the same at this point. Of course, he does change it a bit for each location. New Jersey got a Giants mention, as he compared his underdog status to that of the Giants facing the Patriots. Clinton was doing the same thing that day, which didn't really fit as well, as she has never been the underdog. Well, you could say that she was trying to tie in the "New York" thing, but she doesn't consider them a New York team, so d'oh for her. He did his "Change" thing and talked about Iraq, outsourcing (fine those bastard companies!), and energy. He also talked a bit about his work as a community organizer, which was his rebuttal to the Clintons stating he was inexperienced and naive. He's just a powerful speaker, and it's so reassuring after 8 years of listening to President Bush butcher speeches left and right. He makes me happy, which is a hell of a thing to say about a politician. Usually, we either just put up with them or want to slap them silly. Anyway, the place holds about 20,000, although the top part of the arena was blocked off with black curtains, so it may have held less. The combination of it being a Monday morning in a Super Bowl-hung-over state that is right in Hillary Clinton's backyard made the turn-out to be smaller than expected. About 3,000 people showed up and a big portion of them decided to stand closer to the stage rather than sit, so there were a lot of empty chairs. The position of the media made the seats in back of them virtually inaccessible to most people, as they want the crowd in front of the camera, like this: Liz and I entered the place at around 10:15, and I sure as hell wasn't planning to stand for more than two hours with the rebellion that was taking place in my stomach. We sat off to the side, so we were farther away than we would have liked, but we had a good view. The only problem was that there was a lady whose hair kept blocking the bottom part of my pictures and driving me nuts. Some New Jersey politicians were the first ones up and they talked Obama up. I took pictures, but they all came out horribly. Liz got a sign, but didn't freakin' move fast enough so that I can get past her to get my own. Here she is, bragging about her sign: Then came our first surprise guest of the day: Yeah, that's right, Robert De Niro. Vito Corleone, baby! Hallelujah! Liz went absolutely nuts. I was a bit calmer, even though I worshipped the guy during my middle school/high school years. OK, I was in love with him. It started out with Heat and then escalated with repeated viewings of The Godfather Part II and I just starting writing "Castiglia De Niro" all over the place, right next to "Castiglia Hetfield" and "Castiglia Hart." I probably would have zeroed in on Al Pacino sooner, but my best friend at the time had claimed him and we resolved never to claim the other girl's Corleone lest we get into an argument. But I digress. He told us that this was his first political speech because he never felt inspired by anyone but that all changed with Obama. He also said that Obama's inexperience in Washington means that he doesn't have all those special interest ties that bog down the decision-making process in DC, which is always a good point to bring up, especially since he's not fueled by lobbyist money. It was a good little speech and I was making fun of Liz going all nuts throughout it while training my camera to the big screen to catch Obama's entrance when this happened: You want to know why the shot is a bit lopsided? Because I ended up freaking the hell out. Kennedys! TWO OF 'EM! IN THE SAME ROOM AS ME. I'm lucky I didn't drop the camera. Seriously. Ted Kennedy! JFK's little brother! Holy crap. I expected them to be at Boston and I was wishing that they would have shown up in Jersey and here they were. I've always had a soft spot for them, because, OK, another trip down memory lane: when I was in elementary school, I had to do a book report on a biography and I chose a JFK one. Now, seeing as how my age was still either in the single digits or just coming into the double-digits, I got a sanitized version of his life story: no infidelities and no mob stuff, just wife, kids, and the good he did for the nation before being assassinated. I think that was the first time that I found out that his younger brother was also assassinated and I cried because it was so unfair. Ted Kennedy was the only brother left, and he had to be the father-figure to 13 kids and that stayed with me to the point that I even have to admit that I turn a blind-eye to a lot of what they all did. So, yeah, I finally saw Ted Kennedy. !! !!! I wasn't the only one overcome with emotion, I see! Kennedy came out with Obama, so it was an expected freak-out on top of an unexpected freak-out, which led to more lopsidedness: Obama stated that it took real unity to get Kennedy to come into New Jersey after his Patriots had lost. We all laughed at him and he took it in great humor, but he was sobbing on the inside and it leaked out a bit: Or he may have sneezed/yawned, who knows? Caroline looked great, although she didn't speak. Obama gave her the chance to, but she stayed in her chair. Here are various people rubbing in the fact that they had signs and I didn't: OK, now that's just being cruel, lady! This person didn't take a chance and just brought her own. Hey, flashback to the wrestling show! Except this sign didn't have a drawing of a burger with a crown on it. I mentioned before that I wasn't able to vote on Super Tuesday due to my unaffiliated status. I think Obama sensed this: Disapproval. Disbelief. And, finally, some grudging form of acceptance. I would have if I could have, Senator. Darn it. Hey! Past, future, and, uh, connecting bridge? Deep. The rally ended and the whole mass of people in the pit got to see Obama and Kennedy even more up close and personal. I followed their movements by simply looking for the shock of white hair: I swear, you can land planes and bring ships into harbor by using the light bouncing off of Ted Kennedy's head. That dude giving me the death glare is a Secret Service agent. There's another one transmitting bitchslapping vibes to the man behind Kennedy. Apparently, they only smile when meeting Drowning Pool. Yeah, they were a lot of jerseys in attendance. And Giants jackets, this probably being the most expensive one there. A couple of more shots of Obama right before he left: He seems so nice. And I end this long-ass entry with this: Oh, and this video, which I love so very much. I know the "Yes, We Can" video is circulating around, but I like this one better.

Word of warning: I'm sort of sick and, thus, prone to rambling. OK, so I stole the title from Pearl Jam. Sue me. Anyway, the week has started off well. The Giants won on Sunday, which of course caused some happy mayhem in the streets of New York. I'm nowhere near as big of fan of football as I am of baseball, but screw it, I was thrilled. I do love the Manning family, so any Giants or Colts wins are full of goodness. Pats losing? Just the icing on a very delicious cake. On Monday, I went to the Barack Obama rally over at the Meadowlands in New Jersey, a 15-minute ride away on NJ Transit. I had to miss a couple of classes, but got back "Have fun!" e-mails from both of my professors, so I'm thinking that it was OK, especially since one of those classes is the Political Science one. Hey, this rally could be called field research! I went with my friend Liz, who is a recent Obama-convert, having come over from the side of John Edwards. Comfort-wise, I was miserable the whole day, as I was still getting over a cold and my stomach had turned on me for whatever reason. Plus, it was snowing and we had to wait outside for a bit. The cold also led me to carry a bag full of tissue just in case and I can only imagine what the guards who looked through our stuff thought. The actual name of the Meadowlands Arena is the IZOD Center - I went to it for a wrestling show when it was known as the Continental Airlines Arena, but I don't remember much about it. If I did, I would have been prepared for what was to come. It . . . . . . is . . . * . . . hideous. * Not shown in that second picture: the lens cap of my camera on the ground in a puddle after I accidentally dropped it. I noticed it was missing after about 5 minutes of walking and had to come all the way back, panting and praying to God that I would find it. The colors have somehow managed to make this plain block of steel and concrete look even worse. The New Jersey Nets play there, so what did they do? They wallpapered Vince Carter and Jason Kidd onto the sides. The idea of having the players up there sounds OK. But they came out looking like this: Various extremities are cut off all over the place and the images themselves are all wrinkled. No wonder they want to go to Brooklyn. I think I would have less ill-will towards the place if they didn't charge $5.25 for a Snapple and around $5 for a smaller-than-usual hot pretzel. I was starving, but I was also broke, so one Snapple it is. When my father later heard about the prices, he told me that I should have talked to Obama about arenas taking advantage of their paying customers. Across the street was the beautiful Giants Stadium: OK, maybe not that beautiful, and especially not in this weather, where the greyness of the place and the construction just make the whole thing look gloomy. Hey, it was just waiting for its champions to come home. It'll pretty itself up again soon enough. Of course, since they are the New York Giants, they are going to be getting a new stadium like almost every other team that has its own place and "New York" attached to the front of it. So far, it's very yellow: Contrary to what all this pictures seem to point to, I did not stay outside the arena the whole time. We followed the highly-sophisticated directions and went on in:

So, this dude is back: Considering the fact that he still got one hell of a contract, I'm hoping that, at the very least, Steinbrenner and Co. pulled a Mr. Burns in And Maggie Makes Three:
Woman: Yes? Are you a new applicant? Homer: Actually, I quit and I came to get my job back. Woman: Through there. [points to a doggy door] [Homer crawls through, into Mr. Burns' office] Burns: So . . . come crawling back, eh?
They probably gave him a sandwich platter! And for $300 million, I expect never to see this defeatist body language in the playoffs again!: Well, OK, I say that but I just know that by the time the season rolls around, I'm going to be a softy again. Damn you, Yankees, and your abilities to make me love you! And he's back to his ol', familiar position: Yeah, 4 years is a lot for someone that is his age but, screw it, there was no other choice out there. It's fine and dandy, even though we are going to see much less of this in the last couple of years: And much more of only this: Po, your legs look positively svelte here! What happened to that catcher's booty? Ah, there we go. It was hiding on the other side. Our catcher is so awesome . . . . . . he can hit balls that appear out of nowhere. He's so awesome that . . . . . . little kids use his name to taunt opposing teams about what they'll never have - in this case, Posada in an Orioles jersey. Little known fact: At the time that this picture was taken, Posada had hit 10 of those 20 HRs with a whiffle ball bat. Yes, because he is . . . that awesome. Look, someone who wasn't involved in the trade talks at all! Most probably because he would cost too much. Or a scout saw this and assumed Cano throws too daintily. You know what is scary about these huge contracts? What's going to happen when this guy's contract is up: Ah, yes, our beloved captain and his sweet smirk. His contract ends in 2010, so they should start saving now. You see, the Yankees organization apparently do not get/give hometown discounts. Oh no, the front office will give you what it thinks you are worth - and then add a "The fans will kill us if we let you go" bonus on top of the "The [Mets/Red Sox/Angels] are sniffing around our own player? Our own DYNASTY PLAYER?! Who in the hell do the [Mets/Red Sox/Angels] think they are?!" bonus, even when the first sentence doesn't really apply. Why didn't I ever get his jersey? What is wrong with me? I remember going to buy it back in 2004, but there were none left and I was at that stage where, if I went into a store with money, I had to get something so I ended up with an A-Rod jersey. I need a Jeter jersey. He's like, the default player. I've given a few relatives Jeter shirts because you just can't go wrong with him. Meanwhile, my mother and I are all with the A-Rod stuff, which caused some troubles when the contract crap went down. I had the no-name jersey, which meant it would had to have been put into retirement until someone I could stand wore #13 again. My mother had the shirt and I heard, "Que voy hacer con esto?! PORQUE LO COMPRE?! PORQUE?!" a few times before I told her that she could still wear it - just with something over it, I guess. Then A-Rod came back and her shirt is back in fashion, but she's still sort of grumbling. I actually took that shirt to London with me and got asked for directions while wearing it, since, apparently, a Yankees shirt AND hat was what really made me blend in that one time. Weirdness. Anyway. This sign kept waving in front of my friend and me whenever Jeter went up: The girl holding it? Was, like, NINE. Apparently, you're never too young to appreciate this: Oh, I have more to say about the clusterfuck that was this year's winter meetings but, alas, not in this entry. For now, I shall leave you with that last shot.

Your wankiness is showing, Mr. Rodriguez. No, really. I have no problems with A-Rod opting out. It's a business and stuff happens, so whatever. But, mah Gawd, man, he sure did it in the most assholish way possible and with the most bullshittiest excuse. It was so bad that I just had to make up words right on the spot. What a way to overshadow the World Series. And, like I said, I understand it's a business, but don't treat the fans and front office like morons - we know it wasn't because of the free agents/manager situation. If it was, he could have [a] waited until the 10 days were up to see where the team stood then; and/or [b] actually sat down and talked to Brian Cashman, the man who had stood up for him time and time again, to see where the club was going. And the line that basically implied that we're not focusing on putting a competitive team on the field - what? It's the Yankees. It's the Yankees owned by the Steinbrenners. George is still alive and Hank seems to his own father reincarnated, which is nifty when you get back to point one - the team is always going to be competitive. It's not like Hank is going to turn into Jeff Loria and put a team on the field that is worth about a buck fifty. They came down on Torre hard because of the fact that he didn't lead the team to a WS victory in seven years, even though it has reached the playoffs for 12 straight years. Why is there any doubt that this team won't focus on being competitive? So, yeah, if he didn't want to stay, he should have just had the balls to say it instead of telling his agent to basically break up with us via text message. I always knew he was a pure politician [that whole quick switch in his words between the time Boston almost had him and New York actually got him pretty much did it], but this is something else. No wonder people wanted to throttle him. Anyway, Girardi becoming manager has actually helped quite a lot in soothing me, so yay! I'll miss Mattingly and wish there was some way we could keep both, but he knows that he'll always be one of us, no matter what future uniform he wears. Donnie came in and went out as classy as ever. On a completely unrelated note, I was trying to get a couple a pictures of Pinky a few weeks back and had little luck, as usual. I did catch this little guy in my neighbor's tree: I would say that this is the rally squirrel, but it looks more like the rally squirrel's older, distinguished grandpa. Pinky went outside to the gated area as soon as he saw me put the camera away and I thought, "A-ha! I can sneak a shot in!" I managed to get it, but I also got hit with one very annoyed face. Whatever, cat, I got you. My cousin's husband, AKA Captain Spiky-Hair, sent me a couple of pictures of Iraq that he thought I might like - he promised me more, so I'm just hoping that they come through. Heh. He's currently on his mid-tour leave, which is obviously awesome for him and his family. I'll bug him for more pictures in the second half of 2008, when he's hopefully back for good. Anyway: Behold the arms of Saddam, which have completed their mission: basically, outlive their creator. There are actually two sets of arms in the picture, if you look all the way in the back. The Captain told me that there were either 3 or 4 of these lined up. And one of Saddam's many palace, now being used as a base for one of our Generals over there. Looking at it now, it looks as if he had little pyramids put on the roof. Bigger versions of the pictures can be seen here and here. And now, I go off in search of food. I would kill for a pizza right about now.

So, I went and got a new digital camera today over at B&H Photo and Video. After the England fiasco, I figured that I might as well get my own for future trips. The store was efficient madness - that's the only way to describe it. I got in and out in 20 minutes because I knew exactly what I wanted to buy and was fortunate enough to be attended to by Sales Person #09J [according to my receipt], who sped me through the transaction and was very friendly while doing so. Technically, you're supposed to get on three lines: one to order, one to pay, and one to pick up your items. I didn't have to do the first step since, hey, he's right there! They took all my stuff into this bucket, which was then transported by conveyor belt to the pick-up point in the front of the store while you pay the cashier. Efficient madness, I tell you. Anyway, I suck as a photographer. I just wanted something to take pictures of the family and with enough zoom to get shots of baseball players in which you could tell who they actually are. I really, really suck at photography, though. Heh. I need to learn all that ISO/Shutter Speed/Macro stuff to get the most out of my camera. I also wanted to take pictures of my Pinky, because I love him so. I have discovered, however, that he is a horrible subject. He HATES taking pictures. I guess he takes after me, but still. It was a hassle just to get a good shot. I discovered Shutter Speed at this point, since it was all a blurry mess: "I hate you." Here he is, a second away from hitting me with the full force of his bitchface. After he told me to kiss his ass. What's this? A moment caught unaware! ACTION SHOT! HAH! And here he is, threatening to gut me like a fish for the aforementioned shot. However, it was late and he was too comfortable to move completely out of that curved position, which led to this: Rest now, cat, for tomorrow morning, you shall have a bath! [muahahahahahahaha!] Seriously, the fur is getting clumpy in the back, so we can put it off for no longer. Pray for my arms. "" I'm going to the Yankees game tomorrow, so hopefully, I'll get some usable pictures.

A little bit of info on Leeds Castle - it was under royal ownership from the time of Edward I [1278] to the time of Edward VI [1552] and was usually used by the queens. It had a few other owners, the most famous being the Culpeper family. They are known over at this side of the Atlantic for being a huge part of the early history of Virginia. The last private owner was Lady Baillie, who died in 1974. Due to the changing of the owners and its long history, Leeds Castle is really a mixture of the medieval, Tudor, and modern times and the photos reflect that, to a certain extent. Again, we're crappy photographers.



Getting off the train after 45 minutes of traveling - beautiful countryside! Unfortunately, we couldn't take pictures of that because of the train movement. So here is the station. Woo.



The entrance after we past the ticket people.We actually rode a coach from Bearsted to Leeds Castle - the driver, who looked like Santa Claus and was a very, very nice fellow, told us to bunch up together and go through the Group entrance. Saved us about 20 minutes of waiting on line. Which was good, since it took us about 15 minutes to get to the actual castle - that place has a whole lot of ground.



This is the main road to the castle, with some random dude ruining the picture. We spent about 5 minutes on this road before deciding to go through the other paths.



Which looked like this. We went over three or four of those little bridges. This was probably around the 10-minute mark.



Och, back to the loch wi' you, Nessie!



15-minute mark - hey, look, a castle!



Walking to the side entrance.



This is what greeted us when we first walked up the stairs. Well, this and a bunch of swords at the other landing.

The following four pictures were all in one, Tudor-concentrated room.



Busts of Henry VIII and Mary I.



Busts of Elizabeth I and Edward VI. Tapestry in the back.



Portrait of Edward VI, the last royal owner of Leeds Castle.



Original Tudor fireplace - you can't really see it clearly, but it has the Coat of Arms/badges of Henry VIII and Katherine of Aragon. Henry VIII renovated the castle for Katherine back when he didn't think their marriage was an abomination. I think that wooden box off to the side belonged to Anne Boleyn, but I'm not sure since no one took a good picture of the thing. The Edward VI painting was above this.



The painting of Henry VIII in the Banqueting Hall. This is where Tudor and modern clashed, as they had this portrait and some huge paintings and tapestries [you could see a couple off to the sides], but the actual tables and chairs are all set up for meetings and feasts in our time.

..

Part of the library. There was sections on the history of the families that owned the place and on bird care. Lots and lots of books on bird care. This was heaven. I want a library.



Lady Baillie's room. All around the castle, you could spot clothes belonging to previous owners. That's obviously her dress. From what I could get from her decor in other parts of the castle, the woman loved birds, horses, and dogs. There were two big paintings of her three dogs.



The Katherine of Aragon room with a crappy angle. No, it really did not have much to do with Katherine of Aragon, except for being in a spot that she might have passed in. This room is sometimes used for guests.



A replica of the bedchamber of Catherine de Valois, queen of Henry V [hence, all those HCs that you see on the bedspread]. There was a painting of Catherine de Valois showing her bedroom and, from that, they created this. After the death of Henry V, she began a relationship with a Welshman named Owen Tudor - they became the grandparents of Henry VII, the first of the Tudor monarchs.



Catherine de Valois's bathroom.

There were many more rooms - I really wish that I had my own camera. Darn it.



The walk to the aviary.



A couple of the birds in the aviary, which was huge. There was actually another bird which had a sign stating that he thought he was human. He was very shy that day, though. Outside of the aviary were the birds of prey - while waiting for the bus to take us back to the parking lot, I had a staredown with a vulture. He won. He was cuter than I expected, though.



This was one of the spots in which people ate lunch or relaxed. That area inside the wooden fence was used for awesome falconry displays.



The vineyard. They sell their own wine in the shops.





The maze, taken from the stone platform in the middle. We walked around for 15 minutes, passing a corner with a plastic bag about 4 different times, before latching on to this man carrying his daughter. The people that were already on the platform took pity on all of us and directed us where to go. The stone platform leads you to the grotto.



One of the tunnels in the grotto. There was lights flashing all over the place, so the stones went from pink to blue to green. I'm guessing that this was right by the exit.



The face in the grotto. This was one of the greatest things that I saw over there. Beautiful! You walk down and this is what greets you in the little room in the very bottom. Across from it are colored stone statues of what I'm guessing were either goddesses or water nymphs. I actually took a picture of one of them but, apparently, it got deleted to make room for the 20th or so picture of some random dude holding a guitar. Same goes for the black swans and exterior castle shots. Oy. I'm definitely going to go back to this castle if when I go back to England.

So pretty.

=D

I cannot stand this weather. I just - this is so disgusting. The worst part about that forecast above is that it was worse a couple of hours ago, when the humidity was raging on. I kept waking up earlier this morning because the heat was too much. After waking up from what I think was a great dream [all I remember is that it involved Kevin Nash back when he looked like this:



Do you know how hard it is to come by good dreams like this in the midst of all those bad dreams in which I have to harness all my lucid-dreaming powers [or whatever] in order to bounce/glide away from gun-wielding maniacs and/or wild rhinos? Wow, tangent], I gave up and that is why I got fours hours of sleep last night.

Even before I went to bed, things got screwy - our power went out. At first I thought it was just our house, assuming that someone turned on their A/C and the juice was too much, but no: it was the whole block. And, as far as I could see, just our block. So we were sweating for about 30-40 minutes while the houses in the block behind ours taunted us with their lights. Want to see a bunch of people pacing frantically in their pajamas up and down their neighborhood at 2:45 in the morning? Just turn off their electricity during a 90+ degree night and you'll see them within 5 minutes of doing so. It may have been distorted a bit due to the lighting-by-flashlight, but I think I saw pure fear in their faces. I went down to the smaller living room since my own bedroom absorbs heat and opened the door there, hoping to catch a breeze or two. The only thing I caught was the sight of some dude with a dog calling out to one of the neighbors from the block that had electricity. It's 2:45 in the morning, chump, and your buddy's house is cackling at my sweaty self. Dude's lucky I didn't fling a book at him.

I was actually writing a long update before all this happened and I didn't save, so that's lost. Long story short: got my passport, arriving in England on August 1st, and am currently fangirling my childhood hero, who was a pro-wrestler and just plain awesome so shush about little 8-year-old Castiglia taking over the body of 24-year-old Castiglia whenever I see him.

I want to write more but my brain feels like it's about to shut down.
*Snagged and slightly altered from the Replacement Level Yankees Weblog.

So I'm going to England. Actually, I'm going to England and, maybe, France. I have to write an entry about how excited I am that I'm finally going to see the castles and burial spots of the Tudors, but this is not going to be that entry. So I have to go get a passport, which is going to set me back, at minimum, $97. Since the National Passport Center is overwhelmed due to the whole Canada/Mexico/Caribbean thing, it could take up to 10 weeks to get said passport and I'm planning on heading across the Atlantic in mid-August. So I'm thinking that there is going to be a $60 RUSH fee on top of the $97 for just applying. I swear, it's like a mob racket. One hundred and fifty-seven bucks, not including the fee for picture-taking and mailing. And since stupid, lazy me never bothered to get a state-issued ID, I have to drag someone down to the post office so that s/he could say, under oath, that I'm me while I dump about 3293923 forms of alternative identification on the lap of whatever poor worker gets stuck with me. I'm hoping that a credit card, employee ID card, library card, tax form, college ID card, old college schedule, pay stub, check issued by the federal government, and social security card will be enough. I'm looking around for my old HS yearbook, but I think it's in my closet and when I tried to search for my rollerblades a few days ago, the books stacked in there swayed towards me in a very sinister manner. I'm just imagining having to cut off my own arm in order to escape and that ain't right. My cousin [I think - well, she's a relative] offered to go with me and serve as my witness. We were supposed to go tomorrow but I really wanted to make sure that I had everything together and that includes that stupid yearbook, so I put it off - I definitely have to go this week, though. I'm thinking that maybe I should take my mother, as it will carry more weight, like, "Yes, this is the child that I carried in me for 9 months. I told her to do this years ago, by the way. Did she listen? No. So here we are - my child and I." I also have to deal with the fact that I look like crap and will probably continue looking like crap, thus ensuring that the passport I'm stuck with for the next few years makes me look like the Before picture of a Maury Povich make-over. A hundred and fifty-seven dollars? Seriously? I'm going to be so broke by the time I get back. The exchange rate between the US Dollar and the British Pound is craptacular, I'm looking at living on bread and cheese for 10 days, and the thought of being in an airplane for 7 hours kind of scares me, because I tend to get claustrophobic around half past hour 3 on flights to Puerto Rico. But by this time in 4 months, I will have seen Hampton Court Palace, Elizabeth I's tomb, and, if I'm lucky, Versailles, so this is all worth it. Still. Stupid passport.

I just talked to my cousin's husband, Tex, who was sent over to Iraq late last month. Well, technically, he was sent to Kuwait - Iraq comes later this month. Anyway, I was so thrilled when I saw his name pop up on my MSN Messenger because I didn't get the chance to send him good wishes before he left. He was supposed to still be in the US, but apparently, they moved the departure date up. My mother was the one who broke the news to me and my reaction could be summed up in one word: "Argh!" We basically talked about the flight and, um, baseball [what?! He started it!] and it made me way too happy. Heh. I dunno, he's just one of the few folks from PR that I actually really talk to - I'm really not talkative at all. I'm the girl who sits in the corner with a book and an iPod, hoping to blend in with the chair that I'm sitting on. But I can chat with him and his wife [my cousin, Ivy] very easily and it rocks. I really wish he wasn't over there, especially since his 13-month-old baby [who is the cutest thing ever and is nicknamed DJ] is doing fun stuff like trying to learn how to walk and flinging around his need for independence from various big-boobed huggers - you know, the sort of stuff that one parent catches a baby doing and yells at the other parent, "Oh my GOD, he's not using the couch as support! Honey, HE'S NOT USING THE COUCH! BRING THE CAMERA!" and that other parent throws various furniture and people out of his way as he runs and turns on the flash at the same time. Heck, I miss that kid so much and I've only spent a few weeks with him, so I cannot imagine what a father would be going through. He was, however, allowed to go back to PR to celebrate DJ's first birthday and they threw a huge western-themed party complete with a fake saloon, a cotton candy machine, three cakes with little trains and cowboy stuff connecting them to each other, and a mechanical bull that produced some of the funniest DVD footage in my father's collection. Nobody lasted more than 4 seconds on that thing. Wow, tangent. Anyway, it was good that he went back for that, at least. He's going to be over there for a little over a year, so when he comes back, there shall be some rushing to get him up to New York City and to Yankee Stadium for a game since 2008 will be the last year that it be up. And I'm fully expecting this to happen since the dude is indestructible. So, yes, 2008: one extended family, one Stadium, a baby's first Derek Jeter jersey, and approximately 5 pounds of crappy and expensive Stadium food - book it.

I just checked my library account on the NYPL site and I have 13 [13!] reserved items waiting to be picked up: 5 DVDs, 5 CDs, and 3 books. How? OK, I know how but I didn't think they would all within a week of each other. Sometimes I would wait months and months for these things to come through  - 2 of those DVDs have been there since the end of last year.

Why did I even reserve volumes 2 and 3 of The Beavis and Butthead Collection? There are hardly any music videos on them and those were the best part. I didn't know that when I reserved them LAST YEAR.

I'm just imagining some library clerk cramming more of my stuff on one of those shelves behind the desk while cursing my name. Well, my patron number, anyway. I'm going to have to go up to the desk with a wheelbarrow to pick all this crap up next week.

Also, I feel sort of like a tool for having more CDs and DVDs reserved than, you know, books. In my defense, I have a lot of books already out.

In other news, a cousin's Friends-Only profile made me make a MySpace last night. It's here. I feel so . . . dirty. Anyway, I woke up this morning to a bunch of strangers with Friend Requests - why? These are the folks that turn the Comments area into a "Make 500 Bucks Per Week From Home!" spamathon, right? This is all very new to me.

Two more days until Opening Day! With, um, Carl Pavano as the starting pitcher.



Prove me wrong, Carl!

I think I should finally start using this journal to, you know, write. I have nothing to say right now, though, and, I'm busy fiddling around with a Friends Only picture. Well, OK, I'm also watching Tara go all Single White Female on Kelly on 90210. So, for now, here is a photo of my cat, Pinky:
 


Yes, he's turning his back on Mickey Mouse and Veronica Mars. Hey, it's a mouse and a lady with a huge dog - don't judge!
